commits.commitMessage:
Move BX image header generation to HL build

The header (bxImage.h) containing the BX image in the form of C
array and size variables is generated according to the needs of
the MCU build that includes it. Therefore, the generation of this
file better fits in the HL MCU build.

Also, when we do production release builds, the MCU build will
need to be done separately from the BX build (AFTER the BX image
has been signed) and must include that signed BX image, rather
than the unsigned image output by the BX build. So the HL MCU
build is decoupled from the BX image build (although it will still
grab the SensorHub.bin file from the BX's build directory by
default, to make development builds easier).

Rename the 'default' make goal to 'build' for consistency with
the BX Makefile interface and for better self-documentation.

Move build dependencies to a variable that is shared by the
build and install goals, to prevent accidents in which build
gets update but install doesn't, or vice versa.

Make OMIT_BX_IMAGE=y by default because development builds are
by far the most common.

Update some comments.

Resolves: SH-137
Change-Id: Ic1b86371eda7c7c71e65d42320c8db39c67dd9d9
commits.subject: Move BX image header generation to HL build

comments.message: I think in this case, maxBytes of data are read into buffPtr and then buffPtr[maxBytes-1] is overwritten by '\0'.  This means that whatever was in that position is lost. Perhaps it would be better to not overwrite the last byte with '\0' so that the client at least gets all of the data from the serial port.

Yeah, I thought of that and decided that it would be safer to ensure that the buffer was always null-terminated, to prevent possible reads past the end if someone tried printing the buffer contents.  The interface to the function doesn't make any guarantees that any data at all will be in the buffer if anything other than LE_OK is returned, and I wanted to err on the side of caution (like snprintf() does, for example).
Seems to work fine on my device, looks good to me.

commits.commitMessage:
BX module software update

Build BX image into HL MCU image.

Add start-up handshake over UART between BX and HL, in which
the HL module reports what version of BX software it has.
If the BX module is running software of a different version than
what is built into the HL MCU image, the BX requests that the
HL MCU send the image that the HL has over the UART, and the BX
programs itself.

Add option to build with OMIT_BX_IMAGE set to 'y' (without quotes)
to omit the BX image from the MCU build to save build and install
time during development.

Boost UART baud to 921600 for both software update and
inter-module RPC.

Resolves: SH-137
Change-Id: I648a0de0beb09d169028e53f8244459fa7a275d9
commits.subject: BX module software update

comments.message:
It seems like the bxComms component is a mix of two things at different levels of abstraction:
1. convenience function for uart send/receive
2. version handshaking

So the dependencies end up like this:
              +-----------+
              | eRPC      |
    +---------+-----------+
    | bxComms | eRPC hl78 |
    |         +-----------+
    |                     |
    +---------------------+
    | hl78 UART           |
    +---------------------+

I'm wondering if they should look more like this:
                       +-----------+
                       | eRPC      |
    +------------------+-----------+
    | sw ver handshake | eRPC hl78 |
    +------------------+-----------+
    | bxComms                      |
    +------------------------------+
    | hl78 UART                    |
    +------------------------------+

Or alternatively, get rid of bxComms and have this:
                       +-----------+
                       | eRPC      |
    +------------------+-----------+
    | sw ver handshake | eRPC hl78 |
    +------------------+-----------+
    | hl78 UART                    |
    +------------------------------+

The file is only 350-ish lines, and not that complex. It doesn't seem worth the effort to refactor it. Furthermore, if we were to split this, it would create another component and more inter-component interfaces, which would increase overall system complexity unnecessarily. Sometimes it's just better to have related code in the same file, so you don't have to go hunting around for it in a bunch of different files and components.
Thanks for the change, looks good to me too.

And yet, somehow it builds. :)

I prefer not to include from includes, if it's not necessary. There is a cost in terms of build time, because the compiler has to open those header files and run them through the preprocessor, just to find that everything gets preprocessed away. Granted, that cost tends to be hard to notice with C in relatively small projects like this one; especially when doing multiple development builds of the same thing (because the files will be in cache). But, it's a habit I developed in the old days when disks were disks, I/O was slower, and memories were smaller.

It builds because erpc_hl78_uart_transport.cpp includes legato.h.  Personally, I prefer that it be possible to use a C API by *only* including the header file associated with that API. I admit that this convenience comes at the cost of some extra processing for the preprocessor and compiler, but computers exist to make things easier for us.

Yeah, that's a good point. Usability definitely trumps a practically unnoticeable compute time and energy savings.

For Legato code, legato.h is usually the first thing included, and it pulls in those other files you mentioned, so there's usually no usability benefit to include legato.h (or those other headers) from inside the API header for a component.

Funny how we still need to define this to boost UART programming speed : I was under the impression that sft was already set to program the device at 921600 baud.
Oh, well :-).

sft doesn't use either of the MCU UARTs. It uses the MAP's UART. It's a little confusing because the UART peripheral IP blocks are each dedicated to a specific core internally, but they can be mapped to different sets of pins, and those external sets of UART pins are also called "UARTs" in the documentation. So, for example, the chip's UART1 *pins* can be connected either the MAP's UART1 or the MCU's UART0.

UARTF1 is the second UART peripheral IP block for the MCU. It is the one that is connected to the BX on SensorHub via the chip's "UART2" pins.

comments.message: I don't know for sure that it's actually necessary, but it looks like the main eRPC Makefile passes "-r" when building erpcgen.  See: https://github.com/SWISensorHub/erpc/blob/swir/mk/subdirs.mk#L42

It's just that it seemed to work before without the -r... but it also didn't have the -j, so maybe they're related?  Anyway, it would be good to have a comment for something that's unusual and not obvious like that, but I'm okay with it as-is, since it's unlikely anyone will ever need to re-examine this.

Previously we were invoking the top-level eRPC Makefile rather than the erpcgen Makefile (that the top-level eRPC Makefile uses recursively). We didn't actually need to build erpc for the native environment, so this was a bit of a waste in terms of build time.  I also ran into an issue with building eRPC using g++11 which I have submitted a patch for upstream, but rather than trying to incorporate this fix into our swir branch, I just stopped us from building liberpc for the x86-64 platform.

I added a comment to the Makefile saying why -r and -j are provided.

Thanks for the clarification.

Shame they require the -r flag. In all my years of using make, I've never seen that flag used before. I didn't even know it existed. They must have done something wrong to require it. Oh well.

Indeed. Looks like a hack in our Makefile because of the way eRPC is handling it. Let's just roll with it for now if that's the minimum required to build erpc and it also shortens the build time.

Thanks for that David.
What are the consequences of this? It seems you must have overcome this issue, and therefore this is not really a TODO for us, but more of a bug report for eRPC itself, no?

The comment was left in accidentally.  I have made an upstream pull request (https://github.com/EmbeddedRPC/erpc/pull/181) and I have put a fix into our swir branch or eRPC that we will use until we update to an upstream version that fixes this. The fix on the swir branch (https://github.com/SWISensorHub/erpc/pull/4/commits/b94f9e02344d127037ec2c53b4ffbb5074b744a9) is part of this pull request (https://github.com/SWISensorHub/erpc/pull/4).

I will remove this TODO

commits.commitMessage:
Modify resource allocations to support all sensors

Previously the SensorHub project had a patch that was overwriting the
DataHub memory pool configuration specified in Legato. This was no
longer really effective however because the octave.sdef overrides the
values in the file we were patching. So instead, we eliminate the patch
and introduce a SensorHub-specific override file that overrides the
DataHub memory pool configuration provided in the octave.sdef.

Enable heap based fallback when memory pools are exhausted instead of
asserting. It is intended that developers will immediately size the
pools appropriately if they ever see a fallback to the heap.

Also, increase the heap size because crashes were ocurring when
executing `dhub list`. TODO: investigate why.

Resolves: SH-109
Change-Id: I7789e1c1c359f79ba52eb20a5296271816df3ed5
commits.subject: Modify resource allocations to support all sensors

comments.message: Since we are using the ForceAlloc option for le_mem_Alloc(), I suppose it could be trying to expand a pool and crashing when it fails to allocate from the heap for that.
Yes. That was what I expected was happening.  I increased the heap size, and now I haven't seen any crashes or any log messages saying that a pool overflowed.

It looks like I messed up this function somehow.  I'm seeing this in my build output:

    build/hl78mcu/.config:273: warning: MEM_ALLOC_ASSERT (defined at framework/KConfig:145) set more than once. Old value: "n", new value: "n".

Boolean KConfig options are either defined with value 'y' or undefined.  They should never be defined with value 'n'.

So, if you find '$option=y' in the file, you want to replace it with

 # $option is not set

patch 2 addresses this defect.

My understanding is that this is just a comment:

    # SOME_OPTION is not set

Whereas this explicitly disables a setting:

    SOME_OPTION=n

I think either one of these approaches will effectively disable the feature in question.

Most Kconfig language semantics are based on the Linux Kernel Kconfig which has "=n" mean disabled. Other options include "=m" as a loadable module, not much use on a small rtos. "is not set" is usually don't compile code based on this setting in macro-processing. Sounds similar as far as I can see.

> Patch Set 1: Quality-Check-2
>

FYI, this 'if !' (and it's then clause) isn't needed if the `exit 0` is removed from the end of the file. That's because, when the `exit 0` is removed, this sub-process (the code in parentheses) becomes the last thing run by this script, so it will be the last thing to set $? (the exit code variable), and so the exit code from this sub-process becomes the exit code for the whole script.

But, it's fine to leave it.

I tried it but did not work. I removed the exit 0 from end of the file and removed the if condition. But it did not return 1 from the whole applypatch. It just kept going. (I modified one of the patches that I knew it would fail).
I see now that it's because the for loop may not be done. If there's more to do, it will throw away the result and move on.
I don't think we should discard the error messages like this.  That information could be very useful.
This line should be removed. This is normally not done unless you want to always report success, even when something failed.

The text alignment and wrapping in here is all messed up, but it was messed up before your patch.  I think we should fix it.  We should only use spaces for alignment because otherwise we have to specify that everyone *must* use a certain tab width rendering in their editor.  Also, in some tools (perhaps gerrit) you may not have control over what width a tab is rendered as.

I'll send you a patch out of band that you can apply to clean this up.
Thanks, using your patch, I updated the makefile.
Gave it +2 since it's just formatting changes since Jen's approval

commits.commitMessage:
Drive RESET_OUT_N high for DV2

To allow the BX and other devices on the board
to boot, RESET_OUT_N must be driven high on DV2.
This can be removed when DV2 support is no longer
needed.

This just needs a COMPONENT_INIT_ONCE to run, so
a full task would be a waste of RAM, and this
piggy-backs on the CLI app.

Resolves: SH-44
Change-Id: I062bd4f09e3ab55abb1076544882d0c07b9f1693
commits.subject: Drive RESET_OUT_N high for DV2

comments.message: SensorHub was designed such that software would have to drive GPIO6 high to take the BX out of reset. This is not a bug.  I think the naming of the files and the comments should reflect that. As discussed elsewhere, BX might become the master in DV3, so the reset architecture could change for that revision.

My understanding is that the current system design has the BX as the master, running the main Tracker App. DV2 was designed before that aspect of the system design changed. So, it is true that DV2 is working as it was designed. But the system design has changed, and this aspect of the DV2's design is no longer correct.  But, I can certainly review the naming and wording of comments to make it clearer that this is not a hardware bug.

I was talking to Ashish this morning and his concern with the approach of having the MCU set GPIO6 on startup was that it would make it difficult for the hardware team to get power measurements because they could not easily disable the BX. I suggested that it might be possible to use the `dio` command on the HL78 MCU CLI to manually disable the BX after the HL78 MCU starts up.  I believe that this *could* work in theory, but also that this won't work as this is implemented today because this code calls `dio_Open` to get the GPIO handle and never calls `dio_Close`.  What do you think of the idea of calling `dio_Close` and the end of `COMPONENT_INIT_ONCE` to give the option to reset the BX using `dio` commands later?

When dio_Close() is called, the pin is reset back to it's initial state. So, it's likely that the RESET_OUT_N will go low again.

I can add special support for this into the `dio` CLI component, though.

Do you have a proposal for how to solve this? One idea I had was to add a "restore" bool parameter to dio_Close.  If it's false, leave the GPIO as-is on close. The code in this commit could then be altered to add a call to dio_Close that passes false as the argument for the restore parameter.

I changed it such that the dio CLI command has a little special-case code for that pin, so you can now control it from the command-line if you want, but its default function is just to drive RESET_OUT_N high.
Definitely needed on DV2 hardware, thanks for the patch.

commits.commitMessage:
[eRPC] Use BX_HL_COMM to synchronize startup

Drive GPIO BX_HL_COMM high to indicate to the BX3105 that eRPC is
running on the HL78. This allows the BX3105 to wait until after eRPC is
running on HL78 before it tries to call DataHub create resource
functions on the HL78.

It was originally intended that BX_HL_COMM would be driven by the BX to
the HL78 to indicate that eRPC is up on the BX and that HL_BX_WAKEUP
would be driven by the HL78 to indicate that eRPC is availble on the
HL78. A problem was encountered trying to use HL_BX_WAKEUP on the HL78,
so this approach is not currently implemented by this change. See
HYB-179 for an explanation of the issue.

Resolves: SH-9
Change-Id: Ice4b3f3021a1d02ec3cb30fde4bd558fb7487cfc
commits.subject: [eRPC] Use BX_HL_COMM to synchronize startup

Is this required if the thread destructor is also doing the same things?
It has been quite a while since I was messing around with this, but I believe the reason why I had the commented out version below that only calls le_thread_Exit(NULL) is because it had issues.

I wasn't referring to the commented-out version.  I was referring to the ThreadDestroyedHandler() (the thread destructor function).

It seems that le_thread_Exit() should result in the ThreadDestroyedHandler() running, which also calls io_DisconnectService(), etc.

I removed the explicit disconnect of the services and it still works.  Additionally, some warnings were eliminated.  I'm not sure why I had those lines in there before.  Perhaps thread destructors were buggy in the version of Legato that I originally developed against.
This LE_INFO() looks like a leftover debug log message.
There are some whitespace new lines that could be cleaned up in the patch file but I don't really mind since this is a temporary patch. Looks good to me, thanks.

I think those space + newlines are just related to the patch format or git.  When the patch is actually applied, there is no trailing whitespace.  I noticed the same thing initially when I was looking at the patch.
I'm going to merge this. Jen told me his only concern was the extra calls to disconnect the various services and those were removed in the latest patch.

Update to latest Altair GPIO API

Altair made a bunch of changes to their API at our
request. Those have been released and integrated by
the Legato team. We can now delete a bunch of our
Digital I/O API implementation because the functionality
for allocating Altair GPIO IDs and releasing them, as
well as saving and restoring pin functions is now
taken care of by Altair's driver.

We also need to call gpio_open() and gpio_close()
now.

Also move I2C API initialization to on-demand so that
it does not block boot when the I2C pins are not
allocated to the MCU.

Resolves: SH-66
Change-Id: I27a3983f98db2d4218fd53c6ac3f53aaebea445c
commits.subject: Update to latest Altair GPIO API

commits.commitMessage:
Add 'make zip'

Windows users who run builds on remote Linux hosts
need to copy the image files from their Linux build
host to their Windows box for programming their HL78
modules. Factory programming jigs will also need to have
collections of images copied onto them in preparation
for factory programming of the modules.

Add a 'make zip' goal that outputs .zip files containing
the images needed for programming.

Two variants are generated:
- sensorhub-hl78-full.zip contains all images, including mcu.bin.
- sensorhub-hl78-mcu.zip contains just the mcu.bin and io_par.bin

The files are compressed to reduce the time required to transfer
them over the Internet.

Resolves: SH-87
Change-Id: If28d3f7882eb76b77acf9d93636a8eeef09b7586
commits.subject: Add 'make zip'

comments.message: I would think the workflow would usually be the mcu image only most of the time for a developer and only at inception would the modem firmware be updated. Might be better to use a zip_full and a zip only for mcu image only. Sort of like sft_install_full and sft_install that the Legato/module/Altair have adopted. Also, would be consistent with them.

Consistency is a noble goal, but in this case I'd like to be inconsistent with them for a few reasons:

- I think their way of doing things is unclear.  By adding "mcu" to the name, it becomes clear what the difference between "full" and "not-full" is.

- In the medium term, we will almost certainly need to update the MAP image quite frequently, because there will be a lot of changes to the MAP's Octave apps and probably frequent fixes from the product team too. So, at some point we may also need to add a MAP image zip file too, to save from having to transfer all the modem firmware images just to get the MAP image.

comments.message: Does it need file name here?
When "@file" is not followed by a filename, it's assumed that the documentation will be attached to the current file.

No, it doesn't. It picks up the file name from the actual file, if not specified here. This is less likely to cause issues we've seen in the past where people have copied and pasted or renamed the file and forgotten to update the @file directive.

I have tested that this works.
I recommend leaving a link to the "getting started" page on confluence you created as well.

The reason I'm hesitant to do that is that the Confluence page is versioned independently of the source code, so it may become out of sync with any particular version of this documentation.  Also, you kind of have to do the getting started in order to get to the point of being able to generate this documentation.  But, if we do plan to start posting this documentation somewhere (instead of just generating it ourselves via 'make docs'), then it could make a lot of sense to add a page telling people how to "get started" with that particular version of the sources.  Can we add that at a later date?

commits.commitMessage:
Defer I2C init until needed

If the I/O pin assignments are such that the I2C
pins are not accessible to the MCU, the MCU boot
fails on an assert in the I2C initialization.

Defer the I2C initialization until someone tries
to use the I2C interface.  Also, don't abort in the
driver if it fails to initialize the I2C peripheral.

This is more efficient when I2C is not needed, and
is better for fault tolerance.

Resolves: SH-66
Change-Id: I4d662fef978348c72fc239ae46cac14f91677f98
commits.subject: Defer I2C init until needed

comments.message: It seems that this could result in a duplicate entry if LE_CONFIG_FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION already exists in the .config file.

A duplicate LE_CONFIG_FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION entry should not happen in .config without LE_CONFIG_APP_HEAP being set beforehand. From the Kconfing file:

config APP_HEAP
    bool "Enable application access to heap (EXPERIMENTAL)"
    default n
    depends on EXPERIMENTAL
    ---help---
    Allow MCU application code to call standard C library dynamic allocation functions (malloc,
    calloc, etc).  This feature is EXPERIMENTAL.  If this option is disabled, calls to dynamic
    memory allocation functions will generate a run-time exception.

config FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION
    bool "Enable dynamic allocation of FreeRTOS objects (EXPERIMENTAL)"
    default n
    depends on EXPERIMENTAL
    depends on APP_HEAP
    ---help---
    Enable the dynamic allocation versions of FreeRTOS APIs.  This feature is EXPERIMENTAL.

Unless someone manually edits .config and adds it in without following the dependency rule...

But won't there be

 # LE_CONFIG_FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION is not set

somewhere in the file?
Shouldn't we just replace that too?

When LE_CONFIG_APP_HEAP is not defined, there isn't a

# LE_CONFIG_FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION is not set

Here is how it looks like by default (in default.config):

#
# Heap Configuration
#
LE_CONFIG_HEAP_SIZE=2048
# LE_CONFIG_APP_HEAP is not set
# LE_CONFIG_ENABLE_MPU is not set

The other solution would be to have LE_CONFIG_APP_HEAP set by default, at which point there would be a 

# LE_CONFIG_FREERTOS_DYNAMIC_ALLOCATION is not set

In the resulting .config file (and we could ask for that file to become default.config).

What do you think ?
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as ffb81f581c859f6c84150838e630996cbcffa904 by Apelete Seketeli

commits.commitMessage:
[erpc] Add component for DataHub API code generation

This adds an eRPCGenDHub component that allows generating eRPC code
for DataHub io.api.
DataHub API code can be generated from the command line with the
erpcgen_dhub Makefile target :

$ make erpcgen_dhub ERPCGEN=path/to/erpcgen

Resolves: SH-58
Change-Id: I2a728bd5d6c76a12be067212298b4764c591eca2
commits.subject: [erpc] Add component for DataHub API code generation

comments.message: Is this component intended to be used for generating all eRPC code on HL78?  So for example, if we wanted to provide a way for the hl78 to call the bluetooth functions of the esp32, would that .erpc file live in this component?

The aim here is to generate the code needed for DataHub io.api, hence the erpcgen_dhub target name.
It should not be much more difficult to have additional components and Makefile targets for other use-cases though.
If it is intended to only be used for DataHub, then perhaps the component should be renamed to include "DataHub" in its name.
It's a bit unusual to have a binary outside of source control in this location.

It seems like we don't actually need the ERPCGEN_TOOL_ROOT, but instead we need to decide which erpcgen binary is run.  What if we had a variable ERPCGEN_BINARY which does something like this:

    ERPCGEN_BINARY ?= $(shell which erpcgen)

This allows the user to explicitly specify which version of erpcgen they want to use or they can rely on the normal UNIX $PATH resolution mechanism.
It seems like we're missing the part where this target is added as a dependency to the main build

Do we want to have this target being a dependency to the main build ?
It is only needed if we have an application that requires the eRPCGen component, so shouldn't we leave it to the use to run this target only if she is building said component ?
I think this is a SensorHub Makefile and the SensorHub will always include DataHub over eRPC.

I think it might be possible to have the generated code call the DataHub's io_ functions directly rather than having to provide all of these stubs.  There may be some exceptions though such as the places where you need to cast a uint32_t parameter into a void*.  I think this is something we can tackle later though.
This line is much longer than 100 columns.
This should be under the build directory, because this is a build artifact.

I wondered about putting the generated files under the build directory at first because the files in there seems to be under mktools control to some extent (with randomized directory names and so on).

Do you advise we manually create a directory in there to output the generated API files (which are a bunch of .cpp and .h files) ?
Would that directory be under "build/obj/sensorhub/system/component/" or rather "build/obj/sensorhub/system/src" ? (I would prefer the latter)

I think I would have just put it under a more shallow directory that we know the mktools won't mess with.  It's a good point that we don't want to put these where there might be a conflict with the mktools. I was thinking `build/eRPCGenDHub`. But, we could even use something like `./build_erpc` and add that directory to the `rm -rf` in the Makefile's `clean` recipe and the .gitignore.  `I don't think we'll run into any issues with using `build/eRPCGenDHub` though, and then we don't have to update the `.gitignore` or the `clean` recipe.

> It's a good point that we don't want to put these where there might be a conflict with the mktools. I was thinking `build/eRPCGenDHub`.

Agreed, done.

Can just use `erpcgen` here. No need to run `which`.

(BTW, typically, when writing Makefiles, you wouldn't put the `_BINARY` suffix on this. E.g., it's `$(MAKE)` and `$(CC)`, not `$(MAKE_BINARY)`, etc.).
The goal should be a real file with a dependency on dataHubIo.erpc, so that the output files will be regenerated if the input file changes.

Having a phony goal should take care of the output files being regenerated every time it is called, and more importantly the amount of output files depends on the way the input file is written (a bi-directional IDL generates more output files for server and client implementation) and their names are derived from the input filename : both parameters (amount of output files and naming of output files) could change from one version of erpcgen binary from the other.
This is why I didn't write the goal here to be about the output files themselves, but more simply about the directive to produce them (hoping this would be much less prone to change in the long run than the naming and amount of output files).

What do you think ?

Yes, I'm fine with just leaving it as a phony goal for now and seeing how it goes. It will cause some things to be rebuilt when they don't need to, but we can fix it up later if it is slowing down incremental builds noticeably.

For future, I was just thinking we would choose the name of one of the generated files and use that as the one and only goal.

By the way, does erpcgen delete its own output files on error?  If not, we would have to add code to do that when erpcgen fails too.  But with the phony goal, we don't need that.
Good, let's move on and come back to it later if needs be. Thanks.

comments.message:
I don't like checking generated code into the source code repository.
I can live with it for now, but we should eventually change this to run erpcgen as part of the build.
I agree, and I did this just to have the code available for others to and discuss it until we find a solution for this. Ideally generated code will not be checked in final version of the changes.
We have an (albeit unwritten) policy that commented-out code should have a comment explaining why it wasn't just deleted.
This seems like a critical failure.  I think we should be calling abort() here.

The "250" is being passed as the timeout parameter.  This seems to be interpreted as the minimum number of FreeRTOS ticks to block for when calling the ESP IDF's uart_read_bytes function.  It looks like the code will request a larger timeout if the caller to UartTransport::underlyingReceive asks for a sufficiently large amount of data.  Do you know where 250 came from?  I suspect that this timeout might be why you see the server restarting.  Try passing -1 which means no timeout.
trailing whitespace here and in other parts of this file
It seems like RX_GPIO and TX_GPIO only exist so that you can print them later.  This could be very misleading if somehow UARTF1 ends up on different pins.

I think this file should be named "Kconfig" rather than "Kconfig.projbuild".  My understanding is that if you name it Kconfig.projbuild the configuration appears at the top level of the project instead of under the component sub-menu.  I think in this case, it should be under the component
If you use LE_CRIT(), etc., this isn't necessary, and you get more info (like timestamps) that could come in handy.

I hesitated relying on LE_ print directives because anything below info level is disabled on Legato for FreeRTOS and also because printf() is allowed in other parts of SensorHub components.
Will change for LE_ print directives.
The code in this file is not following our HL78 coding standards.  I personally don't care, as long as the component is consistent with itself. But others may care.

Yes, I know : I tried to keep the component consistent within itself since the client part of this component is supposed to be built on ESP-IDF (and I kept the client code in here to serve as a sample example).
I'd rather keep it this way if that's OK.

I talked to Apelete on Slack and clarified this a bit.  The code is intended to run on HL78, but it originated from code that was written to run on ESP32 without any involvement of HL78 or Legato.  It could (and arguably should) be updated to match the Legato style now that it's intended to run on HL78 under Legato.  I hope that we can come back to this and adjust the style after the code is integrated.

Reworked to adhere to Legato coding style.
Done.
Both app_main() and error_handler() should be static.
NOTE: If the sub-components use the event loop without spawning their own tasks, then those sub-components' event handlers will never run.  Maybe that's fine, but it might be good to highlight that.
Not sure to get your point, what do you expect me to change here ?

Apelete and I discussed this a bit on a Slack call.  Jen: What do you think of this?

Everything above the `while` loop is done in the `COMPONENT_INIT`.  The last thing the `COMPONENT_INIT` does is call `le_event_QueueFunction(ServiceErpc, NULL, NULL)`.  The `ServiceErpc` function calls `erpc_server_poll` (https://embeddedrpc.github.io/eRPC/group__server__setup.html#ga0d8b63dd2df6c89ed6026a12b8e5d9af) rather than `erpc_server_run`.  This function should return relatively quickly.  The function then calls `le_event_QueueFunction(ServiceErpc, NULL, NULL)` so that eRPC can be serviced again.  I think this would allow other Legato events to be processed as well since we're not permanently tying up the event loop.

> The `ServiceErpc` function calls `erpc_server_poll` [...]. The function then calls `le_event_QueueFunction(ServiceErpc, NULL, NULL)` so that eRPC can be serviced again. I think this would allow other Legato events to be processed as well since we're not permanently tying up the event loop.

Agreed, done.

comments.message: Is there a reason why this file isn't named "erpc_hl78_transport_setup.cpp"?  That would make it consistent with the corresponding header file.

I followed the upstream erpc naming scheme which is not all that logical I agree.
Will rename since this is now in a directory specific to HL78 port alongside the corresponding header.
These variables don't appear to be used.
Please delete trailing whitespace.  You can see it highlighted in pink in gerrit's UI

I usually look for them in my editor before pushing...
Done.
Many editors can be configured to remove trailing spaces on save (and to replace hard tabs with spaces). I highly recommend configuring yours that way.
should be (const char *).  There is no need to cast away the const of the data parameter.

Why do these members need to be grouped together into a struct?
Why does this struct need to be protected rather than private?

> Why do these members need to be grouped together into a struct?
They do not need to be grouped into a struct, these could be individual members indeed.

> Why does this struct need to be protected rather than private?
Looking at upstream code some of the transport layer were using protected member to allow access from another subclass and I just kept the same model. We don't have any subclass accessing those, will move it to private then.
Won't we always need bidirectional communication?
We will (especially for GNSS it seems) but it is still something I have to test : I went for the simplest use-case at first, this shall come in a next step.
This bug has been fixed now.

Is this file copied without change from Freescale/NXP? If so, can we link to their copy somehow?

If this file was modified by us, we should add our own copyright statement to this one.
It's a modified copy of the erpc sources we are based upon, I'll add out copyright statement.
We are not using the CLI port for our RPC, so I think we should be closing the port if the transport is shut down.
Is all of this necessary?  I would expect platform stuff like this to already be in the include path.
the SPINLOCK define doesn't appear to be used.

This is actually the reason why I copied the original file from the sources and modified it : SPINLOCK is supposed to be expanded to an empty string when not compiling for ESP32, but this breaks compilation since portENTER_CRITICAL() and portEXIT_CRITICAL() do not take any argument.
This change is not part of eRPC upstream, it is only available on the modified version for ESP32 we are based upon and breaks the build in our case on HL78.

Will remove the define altogether, and also I would rather keep the rest of the code as is to stay close to upstream as possible, unless we're willing to submit our changes upstream. What do you think about that approach ?

Could be INT_MAX instead.  Also, I think an explanation of why this value was chosen is warranted.  It looks like XSemaphoreCreateCounting takes a UBaseType_t as the first argument, so I am curious if UINT_MAX is actually more appropriate.  Also, is BaseType guaranteed to be an int?  Maybe FreeRTOS has other macros for the max/min of these types.

As said before, I would rather keep the rest of the code as is to stay close to upstream as possible, unless we're willing to submit our changes upstream.
What do you think about that approach ?

I didn't really realize that this code was a slightly modified copy from the eRPC source.  Maybe we should have a comment at the top of this file explaining where it was copied from and why it was necessary to do so.

As said before, I would rather keep the rest of the code as is to stay close to upstream as possible, unless we're willing to submit our changes upstream.
What do you think about that approach ?
I think the confusion is caused by the fact that the copyright notice indicates that this is a Sierra Wireless original work.
Don't forget to remove this comment.

If this file was copied from somewhere (as was indicated in a comment on Patchset 4), and it originally had a 3-clause BSD license on it, then we must be very careful to keep the original copyright notice (and add our own copyright notice to that).

This comment applies to all files that were copied (in whole or in part) from the work of anyone outside Sierra Wireless.

This is an obsolete thing. It can be omitted from our original code. (In fact, it can be omitted from all code, but I wouldn't waste time deleting it from other people's code.)

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_rights_reserved

Are we using the 3-clause BSD license for our own original code?
Or is this file copied from elsewhere (in which case we need to include the source's copyright notice)?

This is the API for HL78 transport setup : the code matches the style of the rest of eRPC codebase but the file is an addition to that codebase (hence the separate directory in which it lies).
Will rewrite the copyright notice accordingly.
Should we be using a logging function like LE_CRIT() instead of printf()?
I wasn't sure whether to use Legato print directives or not, and I chose not to because of the rest of the eRPC code base which does not rely on it.
Seems like a good choice to me. :)

Sure looks like a copy of this file, with some changes:
https://embeddedrpc.github.io/eRPC/erpc__uart__cmsis__transport_8h_source.html

Every transport layer implementation seems to follow the same file model/template in the erpc code base.
Would you rather have this file stripped of all comments to differentiate from others and justify the use of our copyright ?
No. The correct approach is to just keep the copyright from whatever file we copied this content from, and add our one-line copyright notice to it.
Got it, will modify accordingly for all the files.

We should probably go with the "lite" version, which uses 1023 (excluding null terminator).

http://cgit.legato/Legato/Service/DataHub.git/tree/io_lite.api

This works.

I was thinking something like this: Replace lines 1 through 15 with this:

 /**
  * HL78 transport layer setup API.
  *
  * Copyright (c) 2014-2016, Freescale Semiconductor, Inc.
  * Copyright 2016-2020 NXP
  * Copyright 2020 Sierra Wireless Inc.
  * All rights reserved.
  *
  * SPDX-License-Identifier: BSD-3-Clause
  */

It's okay to add the file description above the copyright notice, and it's okay to add our copyright notice in among their copyright notices.

I added the 2020 to our standard copyright notice and removed the '(C)' to keep it in the style of the BSD 3-clause license, as documented here: https://opensource.org/licenses/BSD-3-Clause.

The '(C)' isn't really needed according to the Berne Convention on copyright, which every country we care about has signed onto.  (The "All rights reserved" isn't needed either, so that could be removed too, to really clean things up.) I didn't remove the '(c)' that Freescale included in their copyright notice, because one of the license restrictions is that we must include previous authors' copyright notices, and that's how they chose to write theirs, even though it isn't really exactly the right style for the BSD-3-Clause license.

But, you can just leave this as you have it, if you want.
Cleaner looks, like it, will replace.
Is this required for use to use the UART transport?
The Boolean, String and Json versions have the wrong type for the "value" parameter

After reviewing this in a bit more detail, it seems like this file should not be required.  Philippe's changes to erpc_c/port/erpc_threading_freertos.cpp add a SPINLOCK parameter to the portENTER_CRITICAL/portEXIT_CRITICAL macros, but SPINLOCK is empty unless ESP_PLATFORM is defined.

Yes, but the empty SPINLOCK is translated as a void parameter at compile time nonetheless, whereas portENTER_CRITICAL/portEXIT_CRITICAL macros do not take any parameter on HL78 FreeRTOS version, thus making the build fail. I was surprised at first when I noticed it but that empty SPINLOCK parameter when ESP_PLATFORML is not defined does not have the intended effect.
I think the docs should be more clear about what is expected for the `uartInitParam` parameter
These don't look like output parameters to me.  What am I missing?

Those variables values are indeed stored in the class's member variables, but serial handle and uart init parameters are actually initialized by serial_open() and serial_load_defconfig() respectively (see UartTransport::init() in components/eRPC/hl78Port/erpc_hl78_uart_transport.cpp).
Do you consider them as input or output parameters consequently ?

I'm concerned about the memory allocation. It seems the handle and the init parameters are only needed in the class's other member functions. Why not just make these members of the class?  Otherwise, there's the opportunity for the caller to mismanage the lifetime of these objects (use stack variables that go out of scope when the memory is still needed).

To me, it seems that the only information that really needs to be passed in is the UART instance ID. Furthermore, the only reason I know what the UART instance ID should be is that I've used the Altair MCU UART API. There should be some kind of clue here. ...Although, on second thought, since we only really plan to use a specific UART port, this could be made a constant or build variable hidden inside the class implementation file. Then the constructor just needs to initialize the serial handle to NULL, and the class's init function can deal with the rest.

Jen is definitely onto something here.  m_handle should be a private member variable of the UartTransport class and thus should not appear in the signature of erpc_transport_uart_hl78_init.  I am a little confused by what you're trying to accomplish with the uartInitParam parameter.  It seems that inside of UartTransport::init(), you call serial_load_defconfig which I think will overwrite anything that the user might have passed in.  I think this function should take a "const sHuart *" as a parameter and then a copy of that should be taken in the constructor and then subsequently used by the init().  Passing the uartInstance seems redundant since that's part of the sHuart anyways.
I agree with the design issue around memory management here, and coming to think about there's clearly a better way to handle those uart objects. Will rework.
These don't look like output parameters, when I look at the implementation of this function. They are just stored in the class's member variables.

Those variables values are indeed stored in the class's member variables, but serial handle and uart init parameters are actually initialized by serial_open() and serial_load_defconfig() respectively (see UartTransport::init() in components/eRPC/hl78Port/erpc_hl78_uart_transport.cpp).
Do you consider them as input or output parameters consequently ?
This constructor function does not do anything but copy these parameters' values into member variables, so when this constructor returns, nothing has been output with respect to these parameters.

The client doesn't need to select which UART to use, or to change the settings, so I would definitely prefer that we kept it simple and left those features out. If we need those features later, we can add them (and the associated test code for those features).

The `m_uartInitParam` member can be moved to a stack variable anyway. The Altair driver copies the contents out of it (and does not hold onto the pointer after returning), so it can be released after serial_open() returns.

> The client doesn't need to select which UART to use, or to change the settings, so I would definitely prefer that we kept it simple and left those features out.

I took the simpler approach indeed because it does not seem like we are going to use a different UART anytime soon.
I agree with eliminating m_uartInitParam from the class since its scope is limited to the init() function : will move it to a stack variable instead.
I don't like that the name of this component makes me think that it is more general than what the implementation actually supports, but I'm not going to hold up the review on this issue.

Just a minor comment:

> eRPC repository url shall be updated in the future to fetch from

I don't think this is true.  Even *if* every change we need to eRPC is accepted by upstream, there is a good chance that we will have the need to diverge slightly in the future. Patch Set 7:

comments.message:
My interpretation of the state machine is that the first operation can be a read or a write.  There is no restriction on the second operation, but the third (and subsequent) operations, must differ from the previous operation.

So these are allowed:
W,W,R
R,R,W
W,R,W,R,W,R, ... W,R,W
R,W,R,W,R,W, ... R,W,R

But these are not:
W,R,R
R,W,W
W,W,W
R,R,R

Is that correct?
I refactored the documentation for the state machine.  Hopefully it's clearer now, even though it's not graphical anymore.
Is i2c_Start() implied before the transitions out of the IDLE state?
Yes. You can't call the other functions without calling i2c_Start() first, to get a transaction handle.

I would explicitly define a HANDLE_DEVICE_ADDR_OFFSET (would currently be 0) and use this as part of this operation so that the fields can later be rearranged or extended without breaking this function.

I left it out on purpose because it's not hard to add that to this function later, in the event that it is someday needed; and leaving it out means less code to read in the meantime. But I can add it.

I think it would be more obvious why the given values are what they are if they were defined as:

    0,
    1 << 0,
    1 << 1,
    1 << 2,
    1 << 3,

A static const is built at compile time, while a for loop uses power and CPU cycles at runtime. Also, if built at runtime, the results have to go into RAM, which is a scarce resource on HL78 MCU. The static const stays in flash because of the MCU's and FreeRTOS's XIP capabilities.

It is extremely unlikely that we will add another bus to the list, because it would require a hardware change. But, I'll add a compile-time check so the compiler will tell us if a member is added to the Bus ID enumeration without a corresponding entry being added to this map.
Well, it is only used here, why not just calculating it?
I almost did it that way, but the compile time map construction seemed more efficient because of the fact that I2C_BUS_MAIN corresponds to 0, which cannot be computed using a simple left shift.
How come the header file for i2c.c resides in another folder?

I'm glad you asked.

i2c.h isn't the header file for i2c.c. i2c.h contains the interface definition for the I2C API.  The file i2c.c in the i2cDriver component is one implementation of that API definition, but there could be others (e.g., on another platform, or in a test harness for clients of the I2C API).

This is analogous to the I2C protocol specification being kept separate from all the chip and board designs that implement I2C.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Component-based_software_engineering
why void* instead of uint8_t*?  I think the latter makes it more clear that the argument is an array of bytes.
I used void* because it removes the need to typecast arrays of chars to arrays of uint8_ts, and vice versa.

I still prefer uint8_t*, because it encourages clients to use an appropriate datatype and not be lazy with endian issues, but there is also the convenience argument for leaving it the way you have it.  I'm ok with either choice.
Why is configureSwitch not a public function
Because the configuration of the switch is done automatically. The caller just says what bus they want to use and the I2C driver makes sure that the switch is configured correctly for that.
I think these enums are based on naming in the schematic but dont factually represent all the connections for the elements on the enum. Do we believe this is the right naming?

I chose the naming to be similar to the bus labels on the schematic because the driver implementor is likely to be looking at the schematic to figure out what bus their chip is on. I don't want them to have to care what port number to use on the switch; especially since this may change from one DV to another. I also don't want to use the signal names because they're just plain wrong (it's one of the changes I requested in the DV2 schematic review that got deferred to DV3).
I added some comments explaining the naming. We can always change it later if we think of something better.

commits.commitMessage:
Refactor CLI automation and package deps

Minicom's default configuration contains settings
that just don't work. Furthermore, minicom's settings
come from the user's home directory or even a system-
wide config file, most of which cannot be controlled
from the command-line. Besides, minicom is overkill for
this purpose. Instead, we use pexpect_serial and add
an lsof check to make things even more user friendly.

The style of usage for the CLI automation is a little
different: an hl78.MapCli object is created in a python
'with' statement, which provides an object reference
that can be used in the same way as pexpect.

Also fix issues with python3 package dependency
checking and installation. pip was being used when
pip3 should have been used.

Switch to using 'dpkg-query --status' to check for
deb packages, instead of assuming the package includes
a command that is in the user's PATH.

Resolves: SH-60 SH-61
Change-Id: I9e24c72cd8f974b976a83b1d47795e39d317761e
commits.subject: Refactor CLI automation and package deps

commits.commitMessage:
Fix GPIOs

GPIO functionality was broken by the latest update
from Altair. The GPIO_RF clock is left under software control
and disabled (the reset state of the clock control registers)
but there is no code to enable it.

pwr_initialize_gated_clks() is called at start-up
to put the GPIO_RF clock (among other things) under hardware
control.

Altair has indicated that using hardware clock gating is more
power efficient than using software clock gating, when available.
Also note that an SDK patch would be needed to perform software
control of the GPIO_RF clock, so addressing this issue by calling
pwr_initialize_gated_clks() avoids the need for another SDK patch.

Resolves: SH-21
Change-Id: I2dbb7488ceab772310a5bdd15822237bacbad700
commits.subject: Fix GPIOs

comments.message:
I'm thinking I should directly clear the bit in the register using

 REGISTER(MCU_CLK_CONTROL_MCU_CLK_REQ_BYP) &=
        ~MCU_CLK_CONTROL_MCU_CLK_REQ_BYP_MCU_GPIO_RF_MSK;

so as to avoid the potential of interfering with other drivers using pwr_initialize_gated_clks(), which changes A LOT of clock settings.

The latest word from Altair:
"6.      How can we tell which clocks can be put under hardware control?

[ALTAIR] Clock gating configuration is defined by Altair's silicon team and should not be modified."

So, perhaps the best solution would be to delete Legato's `PowerDownGateClocks()` function in hl78mcu-src/mcu/swi/system/main.c.
Change has been successfully merged by Jen Chitty

  development. This requires pexpect, so if used this is used,
  pexpect is automatically installed using pip if missing. If pip
  is not installed, an error is reported with installation
  instructions.
- Add a check that jq is installed, and provide installation
  instructions if missing.
- Automate I/O partition programming and Legato Framework Adapter
  KConfig configuration in our Makefile.
- Add a check for whether patches need to be applied before carrying
  out any build operations. Automatically apply patches if needed.
- Add a Makefile goal 'revert_patches' for reverting patches.
- Automate patching of MCU .config to configure the Legato
  framework adapter path correctly.
- Add symlinks to the mcu.bin and io_par.bin files to make them
  easier to find.

After this, once a developer has set up their workspace, they
should be able to use our Makefile to prep a new device for
development (including building and installing the MCU image)
by running

  $ make prep_device

After that, subsequent MCU image changes or I/O partition changes
can be built and installed by running

  $ make install

If the I/O partitioning is not correct, or you just want to
browse the I/O partitioning, you can run

  $ make ioconfig

Any changes you make will be saved to .ioconfig.
After changing .ioconfig, io_par.bin will get built and
installed next time you run 'make install'.

Resolves: SH-6
Change-Id: Icd07ee5c2b6f66143d85e46f1541b8d8f3eb131f
commits.subject: Support Legato rel 0.3.0 with Altair MCU SDK 2.0.1

commits.commitMessage:
Add Altair, Legato, and MCU patching

Add Makefile goals 'generate_patches' and 'apply_patches'.

'make generate_patches' takes a 'git diff' of the repositories
containing the Altair SDK, Legato sources, and 'mcu' root repo.
The resulting output is stored in files under ./new_patches
(but won't overwrite existing files there). If a patch is
generated for a patches/X directory that doesn't have a MANIFEST
file yet, then a template MANIFEST file is generated there.

'make apply_patches' looks for files under ./patches/altair
./patches/legato and ./patches/mcu and applies them to the
git repositories (using 'git apply') for the Altair SDK,
Legato sources, and 'mcu' root repository, respectively,
in alphabetical order. It also checks to make sure all patches
are listed in the appropriate MANIFEST file, and generates
a warning if any are missing.

Also add patches to the Altair SDK to
- move some pin assignments to the MCU from the MAP core, and
- make the Altair GPIO subsytem work even if there are
  no statically-defined GPIOs in interfaces_config_alt1250.h.

Resolves: SH-5
Change-Id: I165c74b5a1094846153a89b9e52040280917df76
commits.subject: Add Altair, Legato, and MCU patching

Provide "uart" command within cli app

The uart command allows testing the uart serial interface by doing a
loopback test on the mcu console:
>> uart echo

Resolves: SH-3
Change-Id: I540abf5969f39dfdc13533665111b8e9539fe472
commits.subject: Provide "uart" command within cli app

comments.message: Should indicate that it's terminated by a carriage return.

I would rather see:

    serial_handle *sHandle = serial_open(&uartInit);
I like it better too, thanks.
I don't see serial_close() being called at the end.

Calling serial_close() actually closes both uart command and the mcu cli application unfortunately (seems like serial_open() always returns the same handle).

Will add a comment here to make that explicit.
Maybe this command should be called "echo" or "loopback"?
Let's go with "echo", that's shorter to type.

This is he wrong error message. It should be something like:

    printf("**ERROR: %s is not a supported command\n", arg);
Should we be getting the port ID, speed, and framing details as CLI arguments instead of having to update the .h file and rebuild?

Right now uart tool is only intended to test uart port on which MCU CLI is already running, so we're loadin default config that is already in place for that : if at some point we need capability to test another uart than the one the CLI is running on, then it will be required to configure the port settings indeed.

Is this a bug in the Altair SDK?  I would expect that either
1) open() gives you exclusive access to the UART until you close() it
or
2) open() increases the reference count of the UART and close() decreases it.  Maybe there is some special action that is taken when the reference count goes from 0->1 or 1->0.

If this is a bug in the Altair SDK, it should be added to the list of MCU issues in that confluence page and an issue should be opened with Altair.

The Altair API is not that smart. It assumes only one client will ever try to open a UART at a time. (And, BTW, there's no thread safety.)

If this 'uart echo' command is going to be permitted to use the CLI port, then it should probably check for that and forego the open and close steps.

Thing is serial_open() still needs to be called to get the handle which is needed to write to the uart (with serial_write()), even though it does not make sense since serial_close() shall not be called when the uart tool exits :-).

comments.message: uint is non-standard.  I'm not sure where the definition is coming from.  What do you think about "unsigned int", "size_t" or "uint8_t"?

Not really. I just felt the code within the body of the for loop was more straightforward that way (but I accept that the for loop itself is perhaps a little less so for some readers). If optimization is turned off, it's smaller and faster, but that's not really a reason. I have no idea whether this code ends up getting optimized better or worse than the alternative, and I've spent a lot more time answering this question than I did thinking about this code when I wrote it. :)  In retrospect, I probably just have a mild aversion to writing code that looks like it's recomputing the same address over and over. Working for years on highly constrained systems with compilers that don't optimize tends to leave some scars like that.

Yeah, I considered doing something like that, but didn't want to spend time on it at the time.  I think there's value in factoring out stuff like that into a shared component that all our CLI apps can use.
I created https://issues.sierrawireless.com/projects/SH/issues/SH-4 to track this improvement idea.

Well, right now LE_ASSERT() doesn't do anything. :(
But, even if it did, I was trying to be tolerant of error.  I wouldn't expect this sort of function to be used by anything that didn't have a human in the loop.  And humans are notorious for making mistakes like that. :)

If the function is processing possibly invalid inputs, then it should have a way (e.g. error code) to express to the caller that the input was invalid.  I don't like the idea of returning a result that looks valid when the input was invalid.
What's the caller going to do about it?

Yeah, somehow this function is actually doing both styles at once. :)

Generally speaking, I tend to agree. It violates MISRA C standards against multiple returns, but I think this is one place that MISRA is over-simplifying their rules in a way that results in less readable, and therefore more dangerous code.

It was something I was toying with. If you add a default case, then the compiler stops checking for missing cases for enum members.  But if you don't add a default, then a corrupt value won't get detected and some compilers with certain optimizations turned off won't check for the missing cases anyway.  With this goto approach, you get the best of both worlds.  Unfortunately, you also get a surprising pattern for some readers.  I think I'll look at pulling this switch statement out into a function, or try to find a way to remove the need for it altogether.
I think the logic is backwards on this assert isn't it?  The declaration of PinConfigList is based on array of size DIO_NUM_CHANNELS.

comments.message:
Just FYI, I like strtoul() and friends for this stuff. It's still not the nicest API design, but I find it more efficient than using sscanf().

There's also le_utf8_ParseInt(), which is a friendlier API design.  You just have to do your own check for negative numbers.  It automatically treats anything starting with '0x' as a hex number.  It also accepts octal numbers with a leading 0.

 >> dio 10
 TODO: Read pin 10.
 >> dio 0x10
 TODO: Read pin 16.
 >> dio 010
 TODO: Read pin 8.

If you specifically only want hex, then strtoul() has an option for that (set the base to 16). This will allow people to omit the "0x" (or not), as they please.
This can be called once in I2cRegArgHandler() instead of every time I2cDataArgHandler() is called.  No real harm in calling it here, though.
If I called it in I2cRegArgHandler, then it would allow a data write of zero length right?  I don't want to allow that.

No, it would allow more positional args than registered callbacks, not less.
Maybe you were thinking about calling le_arg_AllowLessPositionalArgsThanCallbacks() here and re-registering your positional callback each time it gets called?
But, regardless, this works, so no need to change it.

Just a style discussion, not a blocking comment...

I would tend to format this like this:

    if (   !ParseUnsignedInteger(val, &DataCount)
        || (DataCount == 0)
        || (DataCount > sizeof(DataBuffer))  )

The reason being that now we can clearly see the OR terms, without splitting any of them across lines, making it easier to consider each term on its own at a glance.  Also, having the OR operator at the beginnings of the lines pops out the fact that the terms are all being ORd together.  I add extra spaces to line up all the OR terms with each other, so it's obvious they are at the same nesting level, and throw in a couple of spaces at the end just to visually balance things out (because of the spaces after the first open parenthesis).
I ran uncrustify over this which is how this weird line got produced. I'll change it.
I have a feeling that uncrustify and I are not going to be friends. ;)
Should have a help command that prints usage info.
The help message gets printed as a result of CommandError being set to true.

OK, but it will also generate an error message telling you that "help" is an invalid command.
I mean, I guess that's sort of the same, just less friendly.
Good point.  Will add a help command.
Just an observation that Altair's SDK is only providing a *blocking* API here. So, to make this into a non-blocking API, we'd actually be *forced to create another thread*.
Yep.  Their I2C API is pretty bad right now.

They've added COMPONENT_INIT_ONCE for this.  It works like COMPONENT_INIT, but gets called only once at startup.

COMPONENT_INIT gets called once per "instance" of the component.

This is just automatically called if it exists.  No need to do anything special to activate it.  Just declare a COMPONENT_INIT_ONCE block in your .c file.
I didn't know about COMPONENT_INIT_ONCE.  I think it's probably ok for now to put the call to i2c_init() there, but eventually, this belongs in the initialization of the I2C driver.

This is fine, but because your command functions are all the same type, this could be simplified using a command function pointer that gets assigned during the scanning to be one of the functions Usage(), WriteReg(), or ReadReg().  Then the COMPONENT_INIT could just call that function pointer.
